title: Two Red Sox outfielders earn Gold Glove Awards
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Wilyer Abreu and Ceddanne Rafaela of the Boston Red Sox won 2025 Gold Glove Awards for their outfield performances.
Abreu won his second consecutive A.L. Gold Glove in right field, despite playing only 115 games due to injuries.
Rafaela claimed his first Gold Glove Award, leading all A.L. centerfielders in Outs Above Average and runs prevented.

title: Middle school principal in Maine draws criticism after dressing as ICE agent for Halloween
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: James Black, principal of Mt. Blue Middle School in Farmington, Maine, dressed as an ICE agent for Halloween.
Superintendent Christian Elkington confirmed the incident happened off school grounds and is being addressed by the district.
Project Relief Maine criticized the costume for causing fear among immigrant students who already feel threatened by ICE.

title: What Christian Gonzalez said about his head injury
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Patriots cornerback Christian Gonzalez reported he is fine after sustaining a head injury in Sunday's game against the Falcons.
Gonzalez went through concussion protocol and was cleared to return, but the Patriots' offense ended the game with a final drive.
Drake London caught a 40-yard pass over Gonzalez, contributing to his 118-yard, three-touchdown game against the Patriots.

title: South End residents say they picked up 180 needles in less than a week at neighborhood park
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Volunteers collected nearly 180 needles in six days at Southwest Corridor Park, South End residents reported on social media.
Councilor Ed Flynn urged stricter measures against open drug activities, citing safety concerns near Massachusetts Avenue and Melnea Cass Boulevard.
Boston distributes over 81,000 needles monthly for harm reduction, a 22% decrease from 2024, but Flynn calls for further reduction.

title: What Kevin Durant said about Jayson Tatum’s Achilles recovery, chances of returning this year
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Kevin Durant praised Jayson Tatum's advanced recovery from an Achilles tear, noting his ability to dunk six months post-injury.
Durant, who overcame an Achilles tear in 2019, believes Tatum could return during the 2025-26 NBA season.
Despite the injury, Durant emphasized Tatum's day-by-day approach and eagerness to return to the court.

title: Amid tragedy, childhood friends DeMario Douglas and Terrell Jennings persevere in Patriots’ win
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: DeMario Douglas posted his first 100-yard game for the Patriots in a 24-23 win over the Falcons.
Terrell Jennings scored his first career NFL touchdown, contributing 35 yards in the Patriots' victory.
Both Douglas and Jennings played after losing a close family friend the night before the game.

title: Mike Vrabel shares message to Patriots, Drake Maye after nail-biting win over Falcons
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Patriots secure 24-23 win over Falcons despite Drake Maye's turnovers leading to 10 Atlanta points.
Mike Vrabel encouraged the Patriots to find joy in football despite a tough win and uneven performance.
Drake Maye threw for 259 yards and two touchdowns, acknowledging room for improvement in future games.

title: Former Newton Mayor Setti Warren dies ‘unexpectedly’ at 55
author: Audrey Cooney
bullets: Former Newton Mayor Setti Warren died unexpectedly at 55 at his home in Newton on Sunday.
Warren was the first African American popularly elected mayor in Massachusetts when elected in Newton in 2009.
He was Director of the Institute of Politics at Harvard's Kennedy School and served in Clinton's administration.

title: Patriots stock watch: Here’s who stood out and struggled against Falcons
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: DeMario Douglas achieved his first career 100-yard game, excelling as a deep threat for the Patriots.
Patriots' quarterback Drake Maye had costly turnovers but compensated with explosive plays, contributing to the team's victory.
Marcus Jones struggled with height mismatches, leading to two Falcons touchdowns in the red zone.

title: Boston residents say they feel safer downtown compared to last year in new survey
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Survey reveals fewer Boston residents feel 'less safe' downtown; 33.7% in 2025, down from 70.6% in 2024.
Downtown Boston Public Safety Summit addressed issues of drug use, petty crime, and road safety, focusing on improvements.
Retail vacancies in downtown Boston are at their lowest since the pandemic, attributed to increased public safety perception.
